Sacré-Cœur, Paris
================

The Basilique du Sacré-Cœur, commonly known as Sacré-Cœur, is a prominent Catholic church located in the 9th arrondissement of Paris, France. Perched on the summit of Montmartre, the highest point in the city, the church offers breathtaking views of the Parisian landscape. Its striking white dome has become an iconic symbol of the City of Light, and its rich history and stunning architecture make it one of the most popular tourist destinations in Paris.

History
--------

### Proposal

The idea for a new church in Montmartre dates back to the mid-19th century, when the area was a hub of artistic and intellectual activity. In 1872, a group of Catholic activists, led by Alexandre Legentil and Félix Fournier, proposed the construction of a church dedicated to the Sacred Heart of Jesus. The project was initially met with resistance from the city authorities, but eventually gained support from the Catholic hierarchy and the French government.

### Site

The site chosen for the church was the summit of Montmartre, which offered a panoramic view of the city. The location was also significant because it was the site of a former gypsum quarry, which had been used as a mass grave during the French Revolution. The decision to build a church on this site was seen as a way to expiate the sins of the past and to promote national reconciliation.

### Construction

The construction of Sacré-Cœur began in 1875 and took nearly 40 years to complete. The church was designed by architect Paul Abadie, who drew inspiration from Byzantine and Romanesque styles. The building was constructed using Château-Landon stone, which gave it a distinctive white appearance. The church's design was influenced by the Italian Renaissance, with a large dome and a façade adorned with intricate carvings and sculptures.

### Controversy over the church

The construction of Sacré-Cœur was not without controversy. Many Parisians saw the church as a symbol of the Catholic Church's power and influence, and resented the fact that it was being built on a site that had previously been used for secular purposes. The church was also criticized for its perceived ugliness and its dominance of the Parisian skyline. Despite these criticisms, the church was eventually completed in 1914, and was consecrated in 1919.

Description
------------

### Exterior

The exterior of Sacré-Cœur is dominated by its large white dome, which rises to a height of 83 meters (272 feet). The dome is surrounded by a series of smaller domes and towers, which give the church a distinctive silhouette. The façade of the church is adorned with intricate carvings and sculptures, including a large stone statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus.

### Interior

The interior of Sacré-Cœur is just as impressive as its exterior. The church has a large nave and a series of smaller chapels, which are decorated with intricate mosaics and stained glass windows.

#### The Triumph of the Sacred Heart of Jesus mosaic

One of the most striking features of the church's interior is the large mosaic that adorns the apse. The mosaic, which is titled "The Triumph of the Sacred Heart of Jesus," was designed by artist Luc-Olivier Merson and depicts the Sacred Heart of Jesus surrounded by a host of angels and saints.

#### Chapels

The church has a series of smaller chapels, which are dedicated to various saints and martyrs. The chapels are decorated with intricate mosaics and stained glass windows, and contain a number of important works of art.

#### Crypt

The church also has a large crypt, which is decorated with intricate mosaics and contains a number of tombs and memorials.

### Art and decoration

Sacré-Cœur is renowned for its stunning art and decoration. The church contains a number of important works of art, including mosaics, stained glass windows, and sculptures.

#### Stained glass

The church's stained glass windows are particularly noteworthy. The windows, which were designed by artist Charles Maréchal, depict a number of biblical scenes and saints.

#### Sculpture

The church also contains a number of important sculptures, including a large stone statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus.

### Grand organ

The church has a large grand organ, which was built by the Cavaillé-Coll company in 1898. The organ is one of the largest in France and is renowned for its beautiful tone and versatility.

### Bells

The church has a number of bells, including a large bourdon bell that weighs over 4 tons. The bells are rung on special occasions and are an important part of the church's tradition.

Role in Catholicism
-------------------

Sacré-Cœur plays an important role in Catholicism, particularly in France. The church is a major pilgrimage site and attracts millions of visitors each year. The church is also an important center of devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus, and is home to a number of important relics and artifacts.

Access
--------

Sacré-Cœur is located in the 9th arrondissement of Paris, and is easily accessible by public transportation. The church is open to visitors every day of the year, and offers a number of guided tours and exhibitions.

Copy in Martinique
-------------------

A copy of the Sacré-Cœur church was built in Fort-de-France, Martinique, in the early 20th century. The church, which is known as the Sacré-Cœur de la Balata, was designed by architect Pierre-Henri Picq and is a smaller version of the Parisian original.

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi was the second leader of the Islamic State (IS), a militant Sunni Islamist organization. He held the position from October 2019 until his death in February 2022. Al-Qurashi's tenure as the leader of the Islamic State was marked by efforts to restore the group's territorial influence and rebuild its networks.

Speculations about his identity

The identity of Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi was not publicly known, and the Islamic State did not release any official information about his background. However, various reports and speculations emerged about his possible identity. Some sources suggested that he was a former Iraqi army officer or a veteran of the Iraqi insurgency. Others believed that he may have been a senior member of the Islamic State's leadership, possibly serving as a deputy to the group's founder, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

Biography

### Early life and education

There is limited information available about Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi's early life and education. Some reports suggest that he may have been born in Iraq, possibly in the city of Mosul, which was a stronghold of the Islamic State. Other sources indicate that he may have been of Syrian or Jordanian origin.

It is believed that al-Qurashi received a traditional Islamic education, possibly studying at a madrasa or Islamic seminary. Some sources suggest that he may have been influenced by the teachings of Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a prominent Jordanian Salafist cleric who has been linked to the development of the global jihadist movement.

### Al-Qaeda and early career with the Islamic State

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi's involvement with extremist groups dates back to the early 2000s, when he allegedly joined al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI). AQI was a Sunni Islamist militant organization that was active in Iraq during the US-led occupation. The group was led by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, a Jordanian militant who was killed in a US airstrike in 2006.

Following the death of al-Zarqawi, al-Qurashi may have joined the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), a successor organization to AQI. The ISI was led by Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, a militant who was killed in a US-Iraqi operation in 2010.

### Rise to power

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi's rise to power within the Islamic State is not well-documented. However, it is believed that he became a senior member of the group's leadership during the tenure of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who declared the establishment of the Islamic State in 2014.

Al-Qurashi may have served as a deputy to al-Baghdadi or as a leader of one of the group's provincial affiliates. He was reportedly involved in the group's military campaigns in Iraq and Syria, including the capture of Mosul in 2014 and the siege of Kobani in 2014-2015.

### Leader of the Islamic State

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi became the leader of the Islamic State in October 2019, following the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in a US military operation in Syria. The Islamic State announced al-Qurashi's appointment as the group's new leader in a statement released on October 31, 2019.

As the leader of the Islamic State, al-Qurashi faced significant challenges, including the loss of the group's territorial caliphate and the death of many senior leaders. He attempted to restore the group's influence by launching a series of military campaigns in Iraq and Syria.

### Death

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi was killed in a US military operation in Syria on February 3, 2022. The operation was carried out by US special forces, who raided a house in the town of Atme, in northwestern Syria.

According to reports, al-Qurashi detonated a bomb, killing himself and members of his family, rather than surrender to US forces. The US military confirmed the death of al-Qurashi, stating that he had been killed in a "successful" operation.

The death of Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi was seen as a significant blow to the Islamic State, which has been struggling to recover from the loss of its territorial caliphate.

The US military welcomed the news of al-Qurashi's death, stating that it would deal a significant blow to the group's ability to operate. The US Secretary of Defense, Lloyd Austin, praised the bravery of the US special forces who carried out the operation.

The Syrian government also welcomed the news of al-Qurashi's death, stating that it would help to reduce the threat posed by the Islamic State in Syria.

### Succession

Following the death of Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, the Islamic State announced the appointment of a new leader, Abu al-Hassan al-Hashimi al-Qurashi. The new leader is believed to be a veteran of the group's military campaigns in Iraq and Syria.

However, the appointment of a new leader is unlikely to reverse the decline of the Islamic State, which has been struggling to recover from the loss of its territorial caliphate. article:
Don't Worry Darling
=====================

Don't Worry Darling is a 2022 American psychological thriller film directed by Olivia Wilde from a screenplay by Katie Silberman, based on a story by Carey Van Dyke, Shane Van Dyke, and Silberman. The film stars Florence Pugh, Harry Styles, Chris Pine, and Gemma Chan.

Plot
=====

The film is set in the 1950s and follows Alice Chambers (Florence Pugh), a devoted housewife who lives in the utopian community of Victory, California, with her husband Jack (Harry Styles). Victory is a planned community designed by Jack's employer, the Victory Project, a mysterious and innovative company that seems to be the backbone of the town.

As the story unfolds, Alice begins to notice strange occurrences in the town and becomes increasingly unsettled by the Victory Project's intentions. She starts to question the perfection of her life and the true nature of the company her husband works for. Meanwhile, Jack's job becomes more demanding, and he becomes more distant from Alice.

As tensions rise, Alice's behavior becomes more erratic, and she starts to experience strange and unsettling events that make her question her own sanity. The film builds up to a climactic twist that challenges everything Alice thought she knew about her life and the world around her.

Cast
=====

* Florence Pugh as Alice Chambers
* Harry Styles as Jack Chambers
* Chris Pine as Frank
* Gemma Chan as Shelley
* KiKi Layne as Margaret
* Nick Kroll as Bill
* Sydney Chandler as Bunny
* Kate Berlant as Peg
* Asif Ali as Peter
* Douglas Smith as Jeff
* Timothy Simons as Dean
* Ari'el Stachel as Ted
* Dita von Teese as herself

Production
==========

### Development and writing

The screenplay for Don't Worry Darling was written by Katie Silberman, based on a story by Carey Van Dyke, Shane Van Dyke, and Silberman. The film was originally developed by Silberman and the Van Dyke brothers, who had written the story as a spec script. The script was later acquired by New Line Cinema, which attached Olivia Wilde to direct the film.

Wilde, who made her directorial debut with the 2019 film Booksmart, was drawn to the project because of its unique blend of psychological thriller and social commentary. She worked closely with Silberman to develop the script and bring the story to life.

### Casting

The cast of Don't Worry Darling was announced in April 2020, with Florence Pugh and Harry Styles attached to star in the film. Chris Pine, Gemma Chan, and KiKi Layne were later added to the cast.

Pugh was Wilde's first choice for the role of Alice, and she was eager to work with the actress after seeing her performances in Lady Macbeth and Midsommar. Styles, who made his acting debut in Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk, was cast as Jack after a series of auditions and chemistry reads with Pugh.

### Filming

Principal photography for Don't Worry Darling began in October 2020 and wrapped in February 2021. The film was shot on location in Palm Springs, California, and at the Warner Bros. Studios in Burbank.

Wilde worked closely with cinematographer Matthew Libatique to create a unique and unsettling visual aesthetic for the film. The film's production design was handled by Katie Byron, who created the utopian town of Victory and its eerie, retro-futuristic architecture.

### Alleged conflicts on set

#### Wilde and LaBeouf

Shia LaBeouf was originally cast in the role of Jack, but he dropped out of the project in August 2020, citing scheduling conflicts. However, it was later reported that LaBeouf had been fired from the film due to his behavior on set.

According to sources, LaBeouf had clashed with Wilde and the film's producers over the direction of the film and his character. Wilde had reportedly wanted to take the film in a more dramatic and experimental direction, while LaBeouf had wanted to focus on the film's action and thriller elements.

#### Wilde and Pugh

There were also reports of tension between Wilde and Florence Pugh on set, with some sources suggesting that the two had clashed over the film's script and direction.

However, both Wilde and Pugh have denied these reports, with Wilde praising Pugh's performance and professionalism in interviews. Pugh has also spoken highly of Wilde and the film, saying that she was drawn to the project because of its unique blend of psychological thriller and social commentary.

Marketing
=========

The first trailer for Don't Worry Darling was released in May 2022, and it premiered at the CinemaCon convention in Las Vegas. The trailer was well-received by audiences and critics, who praised its unique blend of psychological thriller and social commentary.

The film's marketing campaign was handled by Warner Bros. and New Line Cinema, which released a series of promotional posters and trailers in the months leading up to the film's release.

Release
=======

Don't Worry Darling was released in the United States on September 23, 2022, and it premiered at the Venice Film Festival on September 5, 2022. The film received a wide release in the US, playing on over 4,000 screens nationwide.

Reception
==========

### Box office

Don't Worry Darling opened at number one at the US box office, grossing over $19 million in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over $87 million worldwide, making it a moderate commercial success.

### Critical response

Don't Worry Darling received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised its unique blend of psychological thriller and social commentary. The film holds a 78% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on over 200 reviews.

Many critics praised the film's performances, particularly Pugh's and Styles', as well as its unique visual aesthetic and direction. However, some critics found the film's pacing and plot to be uneven, and the film's themes and messages to be unclear.

### Accolades

Don't Worry Darling received several award nominations, including two Golden Globe nominations for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama (Pugh) and Best Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture (Styles).

Notes
=====

* Don't Worry Darling is Olivia Wilde's second feature film as a director, after Booksmart (2019).
* The film's title is a reference to the classic song "Don't Worry, Be Happy" by Bobby McFerrin.
* The film's production design was inspired by the work of architect and designer Eero Saarinen.

article:
2023 XFL Season

The 2023 XFL season was the third season of the XFL, a professional American football league. The season kicked off on February 18, 2023, and concluded on May 13, 2023. The XFL was re-established in 2020 by Vince McMahon, the founder of the WWE, after the original XFL folded in 2001.

# Background

The XFL was relaunched in 2020 with a new format, featuring eight teams and a 10-week regular season. The league aimed to provide an alternative to the National Football League (NFL) and create a more exciting and fan-friendly experience. The 2023 season saw several changes, including new teams, coaches, and rule changes.

# Teams

The 2023 XFL season featured eight teams, divided into two divisions:

* North Division: Seattle Sea Dragons, St. Louis BattleHawks, Vegas Vipers, and Orlando Guardians
* South Division: Houston Roughnecks, Dallas Renegades, San Antonio Brahmas, and Arlington Renegades

# Players

## Draft

The XFL held a two-day draft in November 2022, where teams selected players to fill their rosters. The draft consisted of 16 rounds, with each team selecting one player per round.

## Compensation

XFL players are paid a minimum salary of $59,000, with the option to earn more through bonuses and incentives.

## Player movement

The XFL has a unique system allowing players to move between teams during the season. Players can be signed, traded, or released by teams, providing flexibility and opportunities for players to showcase their skills.

## Partnerships

### Indoor Football League

The XFL partnered with the Indoor Football League (IFL) to provide a developmental pathway for players. The IFL serves as a feeder league for the XFL, allowing players to gain experience and potentially move up to the XFL.

### NFL Alumni Academy

The XFL also partnered with the NFL Alumni Academy, a program designed to help former NFL players transition to coaching and scouting roles. The partnership provides opportunities for former NFL players to gain experience and potentially move into coaching or front office positions in the XFL.

## Notable players

Several notable players participated in the 2023 XFL season, including:

* Former NFL quarterback, Ben DiNucci
* Former NFL running back, De'Veon Smith
* Former NFL wide receiver, Martavis Bryant
* Former NFL defensive end, Will Sutton

# Coaches

## Coaching changes

There were several coaching changes during the 2023 XFL season, including:

* The St. Louis BattleHawks hired a new head coach, Anthony Becht
* The Orlando Guardians hired a new head coach, Terrell Buckley
* The San Antonio Brahmas hired a new head coach, Hines Ward

# Rule changes

The XFL introduced several rule changes for the 2023 season, including:

* A 25-second play clock
* A "tap" rule, allowing players to tap the ball to a teammate to avoid a sack
* A "sky" rule, allowing the play to continue if the ball is kicked or thrown into the air and caught by a player

# Standings

The final standings for the 2023 XFL season were:

* North Division: Seattle Sea Dragons (6-4), St. Louis BattleHawks (5-5), Vegas Vipers (4-6), Orlando Guardians (3-7)
* South Division: Houston Roughnecks (7-3), Dallas Renegades (6-4), San Antonio Brahmas (5-5), Arlington Renegades (3-7)

# Season structure

## Preseason

The XFL held a two-game preseason schedule, with teams playing each other in exhibition matches.

## Regular season

The regular season consisted of 10 weeks, with teams playing each other within their division and against teams from the other division.

## Postseason

The postseason consisted of two semifinal games, with the winners advancing to the championship game.

Fast X is a 2023 American action thriller film directed by Louis Leterrier and written by Justin Lin and Dan Mazeau. It is the tenth installment in the Fast and Furious franchise and the sequel to F9: The Fast Saga (2021). The film stars Vin Diesel, Michelle Rodriguez, Tyrese Gibson, Chris "Ludacris" Bridges, Jordana Brewster, and Sung Kang reprising their roles from the previous films, alongside newcomers Jason Momoa, Brie Larson, and Alan Ritchson.

Plot
-----

Fast X follows Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel), a former street racing and heist crew leader, who has retired to a quiet life with his family. However, his peace is short-lived, as a new villain emerges in the form of Dante Reyes (Jason Momoa), the son of a powerful crime lord who seeks revenge against Dom and his crew for a past betrayal. As Dante's plans unfold, Dom must once again assemble his team, including Letty Ortiz (Michelle Rodriguez), Roman Pearce (Tyrese Gibson), Tej Parker (Chris "Ludacris" Bridges), Mia Toretto (Jordana Brewster), and Han Lue (Sung Kang), to take down the new threat and protect his loved ones.

Cast
-----

* Vin Diesel as Dominic Toretto
* Michelle Rodriguez as Letty Ortiz
* Tyrese Gibson as Roman Pearce
* Chris "Ludacris" Bridges as Tej Parker
* Jordana Brewster as Mia Toretto
* Sung Kang as Han Lue
* Jason Momoa as Dante Reyes
* Brie Larson as Tess
* Alan Ritchson as Aimes

Production
------------

### Development

Universal Pictures announced plans for a tenth installment in the Fast and Furious franchise in 2020, with Justin Lin set to return as director and writer. However, in April 2022, Lin announced that he would be stepping down as director due to creative differences with the studio. Louis Leterrier was subsequently hired to replace Lin, with Dan Mazeau joining the project as a co-writer.

### Writing

Justin Lin and Dan Mazeau wrote the screenplay for Fast X, with Mazeau making significant changes to Lin's original draft. The story was designed to be a more personal and emotional journey for Dom, exploring his relationships with his family and friends. The script also introduced new characters, including Dante Reyes and Tess, played by Jason Momoa and Brie Larson, respectively.

### Casting

The main cast, including Vin Diesel, Michelle Rodriguez, Tyrese Gibson, Chris "Ludacris" Bridges, Jordana Brewster, and Sung Kang, reprised their roles from the previous films. Jason Momoa and Brie Larson were cast as the new villains, with Alan Ritchson joining the cast as Aimes, a skilled driver and fighter.

### Filming

Principal photography began in April 2022 and took place in various locations around the world, including London, Rome, and Los Angeles. The film's stunts were coordinated by stunt director Spiro Razatos, who worked closely with the cast and crew to create complex and thrilling action sequences.

#### Vehicles

The film features a range of high-performance vehicles, including the iconic Dodge Charger driven by Dom, as well as new cars such as the Rimac Nevera and the Aston Martin DBS Superleggera. The film's stunt team also built custom vehicles, including a heavily modified Dodge Challenger and a nitrous-oxide-powered motorcycle.

### Post-production

Post-production on Fast X began in August 2022, with Louis Leterrier working closely with editor Dylan Highsmith to assemble the film's complex action sequences and emotional drama scenes. The visual effects were handled by DNEG, who created extensive CGI sequences, including the film's climactic car chase through Rome.

### Music

The film's score was composed by Brian Tyler, who has worked on several previous films in the franchise. The soundtrack features a mix of electronic and rock music, including tracks by artists such as The Chainsmokers and Imagine Dragons.

Marketing
----------

Universal Pictures launched a major marketing campaign for Fast X, including trailers, TV spots, and promotional partnerships with brands such as Dodge and Shell. The film's cast also appeared at various promotional events, including the 2023 Super Bowl and the 2023 MTV Movie & TV Awards.

Release
--------

### Theatrical

Fast X was released in theaters on May 19, 2023, in the United States and on May 24, 2023, in the United Kingdom. The film received a wide release, playing on over 4,000 screens in the US and over 1,000 screens in the UK.

### Home media

Fast X was released on digital platforms on August 22, 2023, and on Blu-ray and DVD on September 5, 2023.

Reception
----------

### Box office

Fast X grossed over $700 million worldwide, with over $200 million of that coming from the US. The film performed well in international markets, particularly in China and the UK.

### Critical response

Fast X received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the film's action sequences and performances, while others criticized its plot and dialogue. The film holds a 52% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 5.5/10.

### Accolades

Fast X was nominated for several awards, including two Teen Choice Awards and a People's Choice Award.

Sequel
--------

A sequel to Fast X has been announced, with Justin Lin set to return as director and writer. The film is expected to be released in 2025.

article:
Typhoon Mawar

Typhoon Mawar was a powerful tropical cyclone that affected the Mariana Islands and other parts of the western Pacific Ocean in May 2023. The storm brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges to the region, causing significant damage and disruption.

# Meteorological history

Typhoon Mawar formed as a tropical depression on May 20, 2023, to the southeast of the Mariana Islands. The system gradually intensified as it moved northwestward, becoming a tropical storm on May 21. Mawar continued to strengthen, reaching typhoon intensity on May 22. The storm reached its peak intensity on May 23, with maximum sustained winds of 160 km/h (100 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 950 hPa (28.05 inHg).

Mawar began to move northward on May 24, passing close to the eastern coast of Guam. The storm then turned westward, passing over the Northern Mariana Islands on May 25. Mawar began to weaken as it moved away from the islands, eventually dissipating on May 27.

# Preparations

## Mariana Islands

As Mawar approached the Mariana Islands, local authorities took steps to prepare for the storm. A typhoon warning was issued for Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands on May 22, with residents advised to seek shelter and stock up on food and water. The Guam International Airport was closed on May 23, with all flights canceled until further notice. The Port of Guam was also closed, with all ships advised to seek shelter in safe harbors.

## Elsewhere

The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a high seas warning for the waters east of Japan, with ships advised to exercise caution due to strong winds and high waves. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) also issued a gale warning for the eastern coast of the Philippines, with residents advised to prepare for strong winds and rough seas.

# Impact and aftermath

## Guam

Mawar brought strong winds and heavy rainfall to Guam, causing significant damage and disruption. The storm surge flooded coastal areas, with waves reaching as high as 3 meters (10 feet) in some areas. The Guam Power Authority reported widespread power outages, with over 10,000 households affected. The Guam Waterworks Authority also reported water outages in some areas, due to damage to water treatment plants.

The Guam International Airport was closed for several days, with flights suspended until May 26. The Port of Guam was also closed, with ships unable to dock due to damage to the harbor.

## Northern Mariana Islands

The Northern Mariana Islands were also severely affected by Mawar. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rainfall, causing widespread damage and disruption. The islands of Saipan and Tinian were particularly affected, with reports of downed power lines and damaged buildings.

The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands government reported that over 1,000 households were affected by the storm, with many residents left without power or water. The Saipan International Airport was also closed, with flights suspended until May 27.

## Elsewhere

Mawar also brought strong winds and rough seas to other parts of the western Pacific Ocean. The Japan Meteorological Agency reported that the storm brought strong winds and high waves to the eastern coast of Japan, with some areas experiencing gusts of over 100 km/h (62 mph). The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) also reported that the storm brought rough seas and strong winds to the eastern coast of the Philippines.

article:
2022 Indian Presidential Election

The 2022 Indian Presidential Election was the 16th presidential election to be held in India. The election was scheduled to take place on July 21, 2022, to elect the President of India. The incumbent President, Ram Nath Kovind, was eligible for re-election, but chose not to run for a second term. The election saw the participation of two major candidates, Droupadi Murmu from the National Democratic Alliance and Yashwant Sinha from the United Opposition.

# Electoral System

The President of India is elected through an indirect election, where the members of the Electoral College cast their votes to elect the President. The Electoral College consists of elected members of both the houses of the Parliament of India, i.e., the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha, as well as the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the states and the Union Territories of Delhi and Puducherry.

# Election Schedule

The election schedule was announced by the Election Commission of India on June 9, 2022. The notification for the election was issued on June 15, 2022, and the last date for filing nominations was June 29, 2022. The scrutiny of nominations took place on June 30, 2022, and the last date for withdrawal of candidature was July 2, 2022. The polling took place on July 21, 2022, and the results were announced on July 21, 2022.

# Electoral College

The Electoral College for the 2022 Indian Presidential Election consisted of 4,896 members, comprising 776 members of the Parliament and 4,120 members of the Legislative Assemblies of the states and the Union Territories of Delhi and Puducherry.

## Electoral College Member Strength

The strength of the Electoral College members is as follows:

* Lok Sabha: 543 members
* Rajya Sabha: 233 members
* Legislative Assemblies of states: 4,033 members
* Legislative Assemblies of Union Territories of Delhi and Puducherry: 87 members

## Electoral College Vote Value Composition

The vote value of each member of the Electoral College is determined by the population of the state or the Union Territory they represent. The total vote value of the Electoral College is 1,098,903.

# Party-wise Vote (Projection)

Based on the strength of the parties in the Electoral College, the following was the projected vote share:

* National Democratic Alliance: 527,371 votes
* United Opposition: 404,926 votes
* Others: 166,606 votes

# Candidates

Two major candidates contested the election:

## National Democratic Alliance

* Droupadi Murmu: Murmu, the former Governor of Jharkhand, was the candidate of the National Democratic Alliance. She was announced as the candidate of the alliance on June 21, 2022.

## United Opposition (India)

* Yashwant Sinha: Sinha, a former Union Minister, was the candidate of the United Opposition. He was announced as the candidate of the opposition on June 21, 2022.

# Potential Candidates

Several other individuals were speculated to be potential candidates for the election, but did not ultimately contest:

* Farooq Abdullah: The former Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir was speculated to be a potential candidate of the United Opposition.
* Gopalkrishna Gandhi: The former Governor of West Bengal was speculated to be a potential candidate of the United Opposition.
* Sharad Pawar: The Nationalist Congress Party chief was speculated to be a potential candidate of the United Opposition.

# Campaign

The campaign for the election began in June 2022, with the candidates crisscrossing the country to meet with the members of the Electoral College. The campaign saw the participation of several top leaders of the National Democratic Alliance and the United Opposition.

# Controversy

The election was marred by controversy, with the opposition alleging that the ruling alliance was using its muscle power to influence the voters. The Election Commission of India had to intervene on several occasions to ensure that the election was conducted fairly.

# Results

The results of the election were announced on July 21, 2022. Droupadi Murmu of the National Democratic Alliance won the election by a margin of 132,328 votes.

## Breakdown

The breakdown of the results is as follows:

* Droupadi Murmu (National Democratic Alliance): 644,500 votes
* Yashwant Sinha (United Opposition): 512,172 votes

# Reactions

The results of the election were welcomed by the National Democratic Alliance, with the leaders of the alliance congratulating Murmu on her victory. The United Opposition, on the other hand, alleged that the election was not conducted fairly and that the ruling alliance had used its muscle power to influence the voters.

Eurovision Song Contest 2024

The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is the 68th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest, an annual international song competition organized by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU). The contest will take place in Malmö, Sweden, following the country's victory in the 2023 contest with the song "Tattoo" by Loreen.

# Location

The contest will be held at the Malmö Arena in Malmö, Sweden. The arena has a seating capacity of approximately 15,000 spectators.

## Bidding phase

After Sweden's victory in the 2023 contest, several cities in the country expressed interest in hosting the contest. The bidding process began in May 2023, with the EBU announcing that it had received bids from Malmö, Stockholm, and Gothenburg. On 7 July 2023, the EBU announced that Malmö had been selected as the host city for the contest.

# Participating countries

Forty countries will participate in the contest, including the "Big Five" countries (France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom), which are automatically qualified for the final. Thirty-five countries will compete in the semi-finals, with the top ten countries from each semi-final qualifying for the final.

## Other countries

Several countries have confirmed that they will not participate in the contest, including Andorra, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Turkey. Russia has also been excluded from the contest due to its ongoing conflict with Ukraine.

# Production

## Slogan and visual design

The slogan for the contest is "United We Shine", which was revealed on 31 August 2023. The visual design for the contest features a stylized logo that incorporates the colors of the Swedish flag.

## Stage design

The stage design for the contest was revealed on 24 October 2023. The stage features a large, circular performance area surrounded by a series of curved LED screens.

## Postcards

The postcards for the contest were filmed in various locations throughout Sweden, including Stockholm, Gothenburg, and Malmö.

## Presenters

The contest will be hosted by four presenters: Måns Zelmerlöw, Farah Abadi, Jesper Rönndahl, and Edward af Sillén.

## Security

The EBU has announced that it will take additional security measures to ensure the safety of participants and spectators. These measures include increased security checks at the venue and a ban on liquids in the auditorium.

# Format

## Voting system and contest structure

The contest will feature a combination of jury and public voting. Each country will award points to its top ten songs, with the jury and public votes combined to determine the overall winner.

## Semi-final allocation draw

The semi-final allocation draw took place on 31 January 2024. The draw determined which countries would perform in which semi-final, as well as the running order for each semi-final.

article:
Slavery in Ancient Rome

Slavery was a ubiquitous institution in ancient Rome, with slaves making up a significant portion of the population. The Roman reliance on slave labor was so great that it has been estimated that slaves comprised approximately 15% to 20% of the population, with some estimates as high as 30%. Slavery was a fundamental aspect of Roman society, with slaves playing a crucial role in the economy, politics, and culture of ancient Rome.

# Origins

The origins of slavery in ancient Rome are complex and multifaceted. While it is difficult to pinpoint an exact starting point, it is clear that slavery was present in Rome from a very early period.

## Enslavement of Roman citizens

One of the most significant sources of slaves in ancient Rome was the enslavement of Roman citizens. This could occur through a variety of means, including debt, crime, and war. Roman citizens who were unable to pay their debts could be sold into slavery, a practice known as nexum. Additionally, Roman citizens who were convicted of certain crimes could be sentenced to slavery as a form of punishment. Finally, Roman citizens who were taken prisoner during times of war could be sold into slavery.

# The slave in Roman law and society

Slaves played a significant role in Roman law and society. While they were considered to be property, they were also recognized as having some basic rights.

## Marriage and family

Slaves were allowed to form families and get married, although their marriages were not recognized as legally binding. Slave owners could also recognize the marriages of their slaves, and in some cases, even provide them with a small dowry.

## Peculium

Slaves were allowed to accumulate a small amount of property, known as peculium, which was considered to be their own. This could include money, clothing, and other personal items.

## Manumission

Slaves could be freed through a process known as manumission. This could occur through a variety of means, including a formal declaration of freedom, a will, or a public ceremony.

## Freedmen

Freed slaves, known as freedmen, were considered to be full citizens of Rome. They were allowed to vote, hold public office, and own property.

## Dediticii

Dediticii were slaves who had been captured during times of war. They were considered to be the property of the Roman state, and were often used as laborers on public projects.

# Causes of enslavement

There were a variety of causes of enslavement in ancient Rome.

## War captives

War captives were a significant source of slaves in ancient Rome. Prisoners of war could be sold into slavery, and were often used as laborers on public projects.

### Captivi in Roman culture

Captivi, or war captives, played a significant role in Roman culture. They were often paraded through the streets as part of a triumph, and were considered to be a symbol of Roman power and prestige.

## Piracy and kidnapping

Piracy and kidnapping were also significant sources of slaves in ancient Rome. Pirates would often capture people and sell them into slavery, while kidnappers would steal children and sell them to slave traders.

## Vernae

Vernae were slaves who were born into slavery. They were considered to be the property of their slave owners, and were often used as laborers on farms and estates.

### Alumni

Alumni were slaves who were raised by their slave owners. They were often used as laborers on farms and estates, and were considered to be highly valued.

## Child labor

Child labor was a significant aspect of slavery in ancient Rome. Children as young as five or six years old could be forced to work long hours in difficult conditions.

### Child abandonment

Child abandonment was a significant problem in ancient Rome. Parents who were unable to care for their children would often abandon them, leaving them

article:
Taylor Hawkins

Taylor Hawkins was an American musician, best known as the drummer for the rock band Foo Fighters. He was also a vocalist and songwriter, and had a successful career as a solo artist and with various other projects.

#Early life

Oliver Taylor Hawkins was born on February 17, 1972, in Fort Worth, Texas. He grew up in Laguna Beach, California, and developed an interest in music at an early age. Hawkins began playing drums at the age of 10 and was influenced by a wide range of musical genres, including rock, pop, and jazz.

#Career

##Early career

Before joining Foo Fighters, Hawkins played drums for the Canadian rock band Alanis Morissette. He joined the band in 1995 and appeared on their album "Jagged Little Pill". Hawkins also toured extensively with Morissette, performing at numerous concerts and festivals.

##Foo Fighters

In 1997, Hawkins joined Foo Fighters as the band's drummer, replacing William Goldsmith. He made his debut with the band on their second album "The Colour and the Shape", which was released in 1997. Hawkins went on to become an integral part of the band, appearing on numerous albums and singles, including "There is Nothing Left to Lose", "One by One", "In Your Honor", "Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace", "Wasting Light", "Sonic Highways", "Concrete and Gold", and "Medicine at Midnight".

##Other projects

In addition to his work with Foo Fighters, Hawkins was involved in various other musical projects. He formed the band Taylor Hawkins and the Coattail Riders, which released three albums: "Taylor Hawkins and the Coattail Riders", "Red Light Fever", and "Get the Money". Hawkins also played drums for the band Nighttime Boogie Association, and appeared on their album "Axel". He also played drums for NHC, a band formed with Jane's Addiction members Dave Navarro and Chris Chaney.

#Influences

Hawkins' drumming style was influenced by a wide range of musicians, including John Bonham, Ringo Starr, and Neil Peart. He was also influenced by the music of The Beatles, Led Zeppelin, and Queen.

#Equipment

Hawkins was known for his extensive drum kit, which included a variety of snares, toms, and cymbals. He was endorsed by the drum manufacturer Gretsch and the cymbal manufacturer Zildjian.

#Personal life

Hawkins was married to Alison Hawkins, and the couple had three children together. He was known for his outgoing personality and was widely respected by his peers in the music industry.

#Death

Taylor Hawkins passed away on March 25, 2022, at the age of 50. He was found dead in his hotel room in Bogotá, Colombia, where Foo Fighters were scheduled to perform at the Estéreo Picnic festival.

##Tribute concerts

Following Hawkins' death, numerous tribute concerts were held in his honor. Foo Fighters announced a series of tribute concerts, which took place in London, Los Angeles, and New York City. The concerts featured a wide range of musicians, including Alanis Morissette, Travis Barker, and Brian May.

article:
Reindeer
================

The reindeer (Rangifer tarandus), also known as the caribou in North America, is a species of deer that is well adapted to the harsh, cold conditions of the Arctic and subarctic regions. Reindeer are found in the northern parts of Europe, Asia, and North America, and are known for their distinctive antlers, thick coats, and ability to survive in extreme cold.

Description
------------

Reindeer are medium-sized deer, with adults typically weighing between 100 and 200 kg (220-440 lb). They have a stocky build and a short, compact body, with a distinctive set of antlers that are grown by both males and females. Reindeer have a thick coat of fur that helps to keep them warm in cold temperatures, and their hooves are specially adapted to provide traction on snow and ice.

Status
--------

Reindeer are listed as "Vulnerable" on the IUCN Red List, due to a decline in their population over the past few decades. The main threats to reindeer populations are habitat loss and fragmentation, climate change, and hunting. In some areas, reindeer are also threatened by the expansion of agricultural land, mining, and other human activities.

Naming
-------

The name "reindeer" comes from the Old Norse word "hreinn", which means "deer". In North America, the species is known as the "caribou", which is a French-Canadian word that is derived from the Mi'kmaq word "kalibu", meaning "shoveler" or "scraper". This refers to the way that caribou use their hooves to scrape away snow and ice to find food.

Evolution
----------

Reindeer are believed to have evolved from a common ancestor with other deer species during the Pleistocene era, around 2-3 million years ago. They are thought to have originated in the northern parts of Europe and Asia, where they adapted to the cold, harsh conditions of the Arctic and subarctic regions.

Taxonomy
----------

### Naming and research on museum collections

The taxonomy of reindeer has been the subject of much debate and research over the years. In the past, reindeer were classified as a single species, Rangifer tarandus, with several subspecies. However, more recent research has suggested that there may be several distinct species of reindeer, including Rangifer tarandus, Rangifer pearyi, and Rangifer philippii.

### Biological exploration expeditions

Biological exploration expeditions have played an important role in the study of reindeer taxonomy. These expeditions have allowed scientists to collect data on reindeer populations in different parts of the world, and to study the genetic and morphological characteristics of different populations.

### Reclassification

In recent years, there has been a reclassification of reindeer taxonomy, based on genetic, molecular, and archaeological evidence. This has led to the recognition of several distinct species of reindeer, including Rangifer tarandus, Rangifer pearyi, and Rangifer philippii.

#### Ecotypes

Reindeer can be divided into several ecotypes, based on their adaptation to different environments. These ecotypes include the tundra reindeer, the forest reindeer, and the Arctic reindeer. Each of these ecotypes has distinct morphological and behavioral characteristics, adapted to the specific conditions of their environment.

#### Genetic, molecular, and archaeological evidence

Genetic, molecular, and archaeological evidence have all been used to study the taxonomy of reindeer. These methods have allowed scientists to reconstruct the evolutionary history of reindeer, and to identify distinct species and subspecies.

#### Novel genetics-based clades

Recent studies have identified novel genetics-based clades of reindeer, which are not recognized by traditional taxonomy. These clades are based on genetic differences between different populations of reindeer, and may represent distinct species or subspecies.

Species and subspecies
----------------------

There are several species and subspecies of reindeer, including:

* Rangifer tarandus (reindeer)
* Rangifer pearyi (Peary caribou)
* Rangifer philippii (Philippi's caribou)
* Rangifer arcticus (Arctic caribou)
* Rangifer foresti (forest caribou)

Physical characteristics
-----------------------

### Antlers

Reindeer are known for their distinctive antlers, which are grown by both males and females. Antlers are made of bone and are grown and shed annually. They are used for defense, fighting, and attracting mates.

### Pelt

Reindeer have a thick coat of fur, known as a pelt, which helps to keep them warm in cold temperatures. The pelt is made up of two layers: a thick undercoat and a longer, guard hair layer.

### Heat exchange

Reindeer have a unique system of heat exchange, which helps to keep them warm in cold temperatures. They have a network of blood vessels in their nose, which helps to warm the air they breathe in.

### Hooves

Reindeer have specially adapted hooves, which provide traction on snow and ice. The hooves are made of a hard, protein-based material, and are shaped like a shovel.

### Size

Reindeer are medium-sized deer, with adults typically weighing between 100 and 200 kg (220-440 lb).

### Clicking sound

Reindeer make a distinctive clicking sound, which is used for communication. The sound is made by the reindeer's hooves clicking on the ground.

### Eyes

Reindeer have large, dark eyes, which help them to see in low light conditions. They also have a reflective layer in the back of their eyes, which helps to reflect light and improve their vision.

Biology and behaviors
---------------------

### Seasonal body composition

Reindeer have a unique seasonal body composition, which helps them to survive in harsh, cold conditions. They build up fat reserves in the summer, which are used to sustain them during the winter.

### Reproduction and life cycle

Reindeer have a complex reproductive cycle, which is adapted to the harsh conditions of the Arctic and subarctic regions. They breed in the fall, and give birth to calves in the spring.

### Social structure, migration and range

Reindeer have a complex social structure, which is adapted to their migratory lifestyle. They are found in large herds, which are led by dominant males and females. The herds migrate between summer and winter ranges, which are determined by the availability of food and suitable habitat.

Ecology
---------

### Distribution and habitat

Reindeer are found in the northern parts of Europe, Asia, and North America, in a variety of habitats, including tundra, forests, and mountains.

### Diet

Reindeer are herbivores, and their diet consists mainly of lichens, mosses, and other vegetation.

### Predators

Reindeer have several predators, including wolves, bears, and humans.

### Other threats

Reindeer are also threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation, climate change, and other human activities, such as mining and agriculture.

Conservation
------------

### Current status

Reindeer are listed as "Vulnerable" on the IUCN Red List, due to a decline in their population over the past few decades.

### Boreal woodland caribou

The boreal woodland caribou is a subspecies of reindeer that is found in the boreal forests of Canada and Alaska. It is listed as "Threatened" under the Endangered Species Act.

### Peary caribou

The Peary caribou is a subspecies of reindeer that is found in the Arctic tundra of Canada and Greenland. It is listed as "Endangered" under the Endangered Species Act.

Relationship with humans
----------------------

### Indigenous North Americans

Reindeer have been an important part of the culture and economy of indigenous North Americans for thousands of years. They are used for food, clothing, and transportation.

### Indigenous Eurasians

Reindeer have also been an important part of the culture and economy of indigenous Eurasians, including the Sami people of Scandinavia and the Nenets people of Russia.

### Husbandry

Reindeer have been domesticated in some parts of the world, and are used for milk, meat, and hides.

### History

Reindeer have been an important part of human history, and have been used for transportation, food, and clothing.

### Santa Claus

Reindeer are also associated with the legend of Santa Claus, who is said to use them to pull his sleigh on Christmas Eve.

### Mythology and art

Reindeer have been featured in mythology and art throughout history, and are often depicted as symbols of strength and endurance.

### Heraldry and symbols

Reindeer have also been used as symbols in heraldry, and are often featured on coats of arms and other emblems.

article:
Meteorological History of Cyclone Freddy

Cyclone Freddy was a long-lived and intense tropical cyclone that affected several countries in the southwestern Indian Ocean and southeastern Africa in February and March 2023. The cyclone's history is notable for its record-breaking longevity, intense rainfall, and significant damage.

# Formation and intensification

## Genesis and early development

Cyclone Freddy formed on February 4, 2023, as a tropical disturbance in the eastern part of the Mozambique Channel. The system was initially characterized by a broad area of low pressure and scattered thunderstorms. Over the next few days, the disturbance gradually organized, and on February 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Later that day, the JTWC classified the system as Tropical Cyclone 11S.

## Rapid intensification

During the next 24 hours, the cyclone underwent rapid intensification, with sustained winds increasing from 40 mph to 120 mph. The system developed a well-defined eye and a symmetrical cloud pattern, indicating a strong and organized circulation. On February 7, the JTWC upgraded Freddy to a tropical cyclone, and the Météo-France office in La Réunion assigned the name Freddy.

## Peak intensity

Freddy reached its peak intensity on February 8, with sustained winds of 175 mph and a central pressure of 925 mbar. The cyclone's eye was well-defined, and the cloud pattern was symmetrical, indicating a strong and organized circulation. Freddy's peak intensity made it a Category 4-equivalent cyclone on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

# The Mascarene Islands, Madagascar, and Mozambique

## Impact on the Mascarene Islands

Freddy passed close to the Mascarene Islands, including Mauritius and Réunion, on February 9 and 10. The cyclone brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas to the islands. A maximum wind gust of 120 mph was recorded on Réunion, while Mauritius reported 10 inches of rainfall in 24 hours.

## Impact on Madagascar

Freddy made landfall on Madagascar on February 11, bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas to the eastern part of the island. The cyclone caused significant damage, including destroyed homes, roads, and crops. At least 10 people were killed, and thousands were left homeless.

## Impact on Mozambique

Freddy made landfall on Mozambique on February 12, bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas to the northern part of the country. The cyclone caused significant damage, including destroyed homes, roads, and crops. At least 20 people were killed, and thousands were left homeless.

# Redevelopment and dissipation

## Secondary circulation

After making landfall on Mozambique, Freddy's primary circulation weakened, but a secondary circulation developed over the Mozambique Channel. The new circulation gradually strengthened, and on February 15, the JTWC reclassified Freddy as a tropical cyclone.

## Final landfall and dissipation

Freddy made its final landfall on Mozambique on February 17, bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas to the southern part of the country. The cyclone caused additional damage, including destroyed homes, roads, and crops. After making landfall, Freddy's circulation rapidly weakened, and the JTWC issued its final advisory on February 18.

# Records

## Longevity

Freddy's longevity is notable, as it maintained tropical cyclone status for 35 days, making it one of the longest-lived tropical cyclones on record in the southwestern Indian Ocean.

## Rainfall

Freddy brought record-breaking rainfall to several countries, including Madagascar and Mozambique. The cyclone's rainfall totals exceeded 20 inches in some areas, causing significant flooding and landslides.

* List of Category 4-equivalent cyclones
* Cyclone Idai
* Cyclone Kenneth

article:
Scientology
===========

Introduction
------------

Scientology is a body of beliefs and practices created by L. Ron Hubbard in 1954. It has been a subject of controversy and debate since its inception, with some viewing it as a legitimate spiritual movement and others as a cult or a commercial enterprise. This article provides an overview of Scientology's definition and classification, history, beliefs and practices, organizational structure, and controversies surrounding the movement.

Definition and Classification
---------------------------

Scientology is often described as a self-described spiritual movement that aims to help individuals achieve spiritual enlightenment and self-improvement through its teachings and practices. However, its classification as a religion, philosophy, or science has been a subject of debate.

### Debates over Classification

Some scholars and experts classify Scientology as a new religious movement, while others view it as a cult or a form of psychotherapy. The Church of Scientology has been recognized as a tax-exempt religious organization in the United States since 1993, but its status as a religion has been disputed by some governments and critics.

### Etymology

The term "Scientology" was coined by Hubbard from the Latin words "scientia," meaning knowledge, and "logos," meaning study or science. Hubbard claimed that Scientology was a science of the mind, aimed at understanding and improving human behavior.

History
-------

L. Ron Hubbard developed the ideas and practices that would become Scientology in the early 1950s. Hubbard was a science fiction author and self-help enthusiast who had developed a system of self-improvement called Dianetics. In 1954, Hubbard founded the first Church of Scientology in Los Angeles, California.

Over the years, Scientology has expanded into a global movement with thousands of members and numerous organizations and businesses. However, the movement has also faced numerous controversies and criticisms, including allegations of financial exploitation, mistreatment of members, and organized harassment of opponents.

Beliefs and Practices
--------------------

Scientology's teachings and practices are based on Hubbard's writings and lectures, which are considered sacred scripture by Scientologists. The core of Scientology is the concept of the reactive mind, which is seen as a source of human suffering and irrational behavior.

### Auditing

Auditing is a central practice in Scientology, in which a trained auditor uses an E-meter to help the individual (called a preclear) confront and overcome past traumas and negative experiences. The goal of auditing is to achieve spiritual enlightenment and self-improvement.

### Soul

Scientologists believe in the concept of the thetan, which is seen as the spiritual essence of an individual. The thetan is believed to be immortal and to have inhabited numerous bodies over millions of years.

### Space Opera and the Wall of Fire

According to Scientology's teachings, the thetan has experienced numerous past lives, including lives on other planets and in other dimensions. The most significant event in the thetan's history is the "Wall of Fire," a catastrophic event that occurred 75 million years ago, in which the thetan was trapped in a physical body and subjected to painful and humiliating experiences.

### The Operating Thetan Levels

The Operating Thetan (OT) levels are a series of advanced auditing levels that are designed to help the individual achieve spiritual enlightenment and superhuman abilities. The OT levels are considered confidential and are only available to members who have reached a certain level of spiritual advancement.

### Ethics

Scientology's ethics system is based on the concept of the "tone scale," which is a scale of human emotions and behavior. Scientologists are encouraged to behave in a way that is in harmony with the tone scale, and to avoid behaviors that are considered "down-tone" or destructive.

### Symbology

Scientology uses a variety of symbols and logos, including the Scientology cross and the Dianetics symbol. These symbols are considered sacred by Scientologists and are used to represent the movement's teachings and practices.

### Psychiatry, Psychology, Psychosis

Scientology is strongly opposed to psychiatry and psychology, which are seen as pseudosciences that are hostile to human freedom and spiritual growth. Scientologists believe that mental illness is a spiritual problem that can be solved through auditing and other spiritual practices.

### Views on Hubbard

Scientologists view L. Ron Hubbard as a spiritual leader and a source of wisdom and guidance. Hubbard's writings and lectures are considered sacred scripture, and his teachings are seen as a path to spiritual enlightenment and self-improvement.

The Church of Scientology
-------------------------

The Church of Scientology is the main organization of the Scientology movement. The church has a complex internal structure, with numerous departments and organizations that are responsible for different aspects of the movement's activities.

### Internal Organization

The church is headed by the Religious Technology Center (RTC), which is responsible for overseeing the use of Scientology's trademarks and copyrights. The RTC is headed by David Miscavige, who is the current leader of the Scientology movement.

### Promotional Material

The church produces a wide range of promotional material, including books, videos, and websites. This material is designed to promote Scientology's teachings and practices, and to attract new members to the movement.

### Social Outreach

The church is involved in a variety of social outreach activities, including disaster relief, human rights advocacy, and community development programs. These activities are designed to promote Scientology's values and to improve the lives of individuals and communities.

### Responses to Opponents

The church has a reputation for being aggressive and litigious in its responses to opponents and critics. Scientologists believe that the church is under attack by a variety of enemies, including governments, media outlets, and rival spiritual movements.

### Suppressive Persons and Fair Game

Scientology has a policy of "fair game" against individuals who are deemed to be "suppressive persons" (SPs). SPs are seen as enemies of the church and are subject to harassment, intimidation, and other forms of mistreatment.

Free Zone and Independent Scientology
--------------------------------------

In addition to the Church of Scientology, there are numerous independent Scientology groups and individuals who practice Scientology outside of the church's authority. These groups are often referred to as the "Free Zone."

Controversies
-------------

article:
Mișu Benvenisti

Mișu Benvenisti was a Romanian Jewish lawyer, politician, and activist who played a significant role in the fight against antisemitism in Romania during the interwar period. Born into a prominent Jewish family, Benvenisti became involved in politics at an early age and quickly rose to prominence as a vocal advocate for Jewish rights.

# Biography

## Early life and career

Mișu Benvenisti was born in 1902 in Iași, Romania, to a family of Jewish intellectuals. His father, also a lawyer, was a prominent figure in the local Jewish community. Benvenisti's early life was marked by a strong emphasis on education and a commitment to social justice. He studied law at the University of Iași and later at the University of Bucharest, where he became involved in student politics and began to develop his skills as a public speaker.

After completing his studies, Benvenisti returned to Iași and began to build a successful law practice. He quickly gained a reputation as a skilled and passionate advocate, particularly in cases involving Jewish clients who had been victims of antisemitic violence or discrimination.

## Fighting antisemitism

Benvenisti's experiences as a lawyer and his growing awareness of the widespread antisemitism in Romania led him to become increasingly involved in politics. He joined the Union of Romanian Jews, a leading Jewish organization in the country, and quickly became a vocal advocate for Jewish rights.

In the early 1920s, Benvenisti began to speak out publicly against the growing tide of antisemitism in Romania. He wrote articles and gave speeches denouncing the violence and intimidation faced by Jewish communities across the country. His activism quickly gained attention, and he became a prominent figure in the Jewish community.

## Against Richter

One of Benvenisti's most notable early campaigns was against the infamous antisemitic politician, Alexandru Richter. Richter was a leading figure in the Romanian fascist movement and had built a reputation for his virulent antisemitism. Benvenisti saw Richter as a major threat to Jewish safety and began to speak out against him, denouncing his racist rhetoric and calling for him to be held accountable for his actions.

Benvenisti's campaign against Richter was marked by a series of public confrontations, including a notable debate between the two men in 1925. Benvenisti's passion and eloquence made a significant impact, and he quickly gained a reputation as a fearless and effective advocate for Jewish rights.

## HeHalutz trial and marginalization

In 1926, Benvenisti became involved in the HeHalutz trial, a highly publicized case involving a group of Jewish youth who had been accused of treason for their involvement in the Zionist movement. Benvenisti saw the trial as a clear example of antisemitic persecution and quickly became involved in the defense team.

Despite his best efforts, the trial ended in a guilty verdict, and the defendants were sentenced to prison. Benvenisti was deeply disappointed by the outcome and felt that the trial had highlighted the deep-seated antisemitism within the Romanian justice system.

The HeHalutz trial marked a turning point in Benvenisti's career. He became increasingly disillusioned with the Romanian political system and began to feel marginalized by his own community. Many Jewish leaders saw him as too radical, too confrontational, and too willing to challenge the status quo.

## Communist turn

As Benvenisti's disillusionment with the Romanian political system grew, he began to explore alternative ideologies. He became increasingly drawn to communism, seeing it as a way to challenge the existing power structures and fight for true social justice.

Benvenisti's turn to communism was not without controversy. Many of his former allies saw him as a traitor, abandoning the Jewish community for a radical ideology that seemed to prioritize class struggle over Jewish identity.

## Zionist ban

In 1933, Benvenisti's involvement with the communist movement led to a formal ban from the Zionist Organization of Romania. The ban was a significant blow, marking a formal break between Benvenisti and the Jewish community he had once served.

## Communist imprisonment and release

In 1935, Benvenisti was arrested by the Romanian authorities for his involvement in the communist movement. He was sentenced to prison, where he spent several years before being released in 1944.

Benvenisti's imprisonment marked a significant turning point in his life. He emerged from prison a changed man, his experiences having deepened his commitment to social justice and his critique of the existing power structures.

# Notes

Mișu Benvenisti's life and career are a testament to the complex and often fraught history of Jewish-Romanian relations during the interwar period. His activism, advocacy, and commitment to social justice continue to inspire and educate, offering a powerful reminder of the ongoing struggle for human rights and dignity.

The Voice (Australian TV series) Season 11

The eleventh season of the Australian reality television series The Voice premiered on 8 August 2022, on the Seven Network. The season was hosted by Sonia Kruger, who returned for her second season as host. The coaching panel consisted of four returning coaches: Guy Sebastian, Jessica Mauboy, Rita Ora, and Keith Urban.

# Coaches and Host

The coaching panel for season 11 consisted of four returning coaches: Guy Sebastian, Jessica Mauboy, Rita Ora, and Keith Urban. Guy Sebastian returned for his seventh season as a coach, while Jessica Mauboy and Rita Ora returned for their fourth and second seasons, respectively. Keith Urban returned for his fifth season as a coach, having previously coached in seasons 1, 2, 3, and 10. Sonia Kruger returned as the host for her second season, having previously hosted season 10.

# Teams

The teams for season 11 were selected during the blind auditions. Each coach had a team of 12 contestants. The teams were:

* Team Guy: Alex Weybury, Ethan Conway, Jordan Smith, Kye Burns, Lana, Matthew Scully, Mei-Ling, Olivia Cella, Ryan Gallagher, Tammy, and twins Tash and Emily
* Team Jessica: Chris Sebastian, Elijah, Emily Green, Ethan Karpathy, Jesse Teinaki, Jordan Raskopoulos, Lachie Gill, Nathan Foley, Raphaella, Romy, and twins Ava and Zoe
* Team Rita: Alexander Widespread, Bella Mackenzie, Billy Burton, Chloe Dallimore, Clayton Crowe, Daniel Shaw, Georgia Capleton, Harrison Craig, Holly Summers, Jake, and Jordan
* Team Keith: Adam Spencer, Chelsea Juala, Emily Williams, Hannah Fawcett, Jamie Munro, Jordan Dennis, Kate O'Leary, Lachlan Edwards, Maria Gaida, Nick Wiesinger, and twins Amali and Eden

# Blind Auditions

The blind auditions took place over four episodes, from 8 to 22 August 2022. During the blind auditions, each coach had the opportunity to recruit contestants to their team. The contestants sang a song of their choice, and the coaches turned their chairs if they wanted to recruit the contestant. If more than one coach turned their chair, the contestant had the opportunity to choose which team they wanted to join.

# Callbacks

The callbacks took place over two episodes, from 23 to 29 August 2022. During the callbacks, each coach had the opportunity to narrow down their team to the top six contestants. The contestants sang a song of their choice, and the coaches eliminated the contestants they did not want to move forward.

# Battles

The battles took place over three episodes, from 30 August to 5 September 2022. During the battles, the contestants sang a song of their choice, either solo or in a group. The coaches had the opportunity to choose which contestants they wanted to move forward to the sing-offs.

## Sing-offs

The sing-offs took place over two episodes, from 6 to 12 September 2022. During the sing-offs, the contestants sang a song of their choice, and the coaches eliminated the contestants they did not want to move forward to the semi-final.

# Finals

## Semi-final

The semi-final took place on 19 September 2022. During the semi-final, the remaining contestants sang a song of their choice, and the coaches eliminated the contestants they did not want to move forward to the grand finale.

## Grand Finale

The grand finale took place on 26 September 2022. During the grand finale, the remaining contestants sang a song of their choice, and the winner was announced. The winner of season 11 was announced as Ethan Conway from Team Guy.

# Contestants who appeared on previous season or TV shows

Several contestants from season 11 had previously appeared on other TV shows or seasons of The Voice. These contestants included:

* Ryan Gallagher, who appeared on season 9 of The Voice
* Nathan Foley, who appeared on Australian Idol and season 10 of The Voice
* Harrison Craig, who appeared on season 2 of The Voice and won the season
* Jordan Smith, who appeared on season 9 of The Voice

# Ratings

The ratings for season 11 of The Voice were strong, with the premiere episode attracting an audience of 1.03 million viewers. The season averaged an audience of 844,000 viewers per episode. The grand finale attracted an audience of 1.13 million viewers, making it the highest-rated episode of the season.

article:
Ron DeSantis

Ronald Dion DeSantis is an American politician, lawyer, and former naval officer who has served as the 46th Governor of Florida since 2019. A member of the Republican Party, DeSantis represented Florida's 6th congressional district in the U.S. House of Representatives from 2013 to 2018.

#Early life and education

Ron DeSantis was born on September 14, 1978, in Jacksonville, Florida, to Karen Rogers and Ronald DeSantis. He grew up in Dunedin, Florida, and was raised Catholic. DeSantis attended Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic School and later graduated from Dunedin High School in 1997. He was a member of the National Honor Society and was captain of the high school's varsity baseball team.

DeSantis received a Bachelor of Arts degree in history from Yale University in 2001, where he was a member of the Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity. He later earned a Juris Doctor degree from Harvard Law School in 2005.

#Military service

DeSantis joined the United States Navy in 2004 and was commissioned as a lieutenant in the Judge Advocate General's Corps (JAG). He served as a JAG officer at the Guantanamo Bay detention center in Cuba and later as a prosecutor at the Naval Station Mayport in Florida. DeSantis was honorably discharged from active duty in 2010, but remained in the Navy Reserve.

##Post-naval career

After leaving active duty, DeSantis worked as a lawyer and later as an adjunct professor at the Florida Coastal School of Law. He also wrote articles and book reviews for the National Review and the Washington Times.

#U.S. House of Representatives (2013–2018)

##Elections

DeSantis announced his candidacy for the U.S. House of Representatives in 2012, seeking to represent Florida's 6th congressional district. He won the Republican primary and went on to defeat Democrat Heather Beaven in the general election.

DeSantis was re-elected in 2014 and 2016, each time winning by a wide margin.

##Tenure

During his time in Congress, DeSantis was a member of the Republican Study Committee and the House Freedom Caucus. He was a strong advocate for limited government, lower taxes, and a balanced budget.

###Fiscal policy

DeSantis was a vocal critic of government spending and the national debt. He supported a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution and advocated for reducing the size of the federal government.

##Committees

DeSantis served on several committees, including the House Judiciary Committee, the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, and the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

#Gubernatorial campaigns

##2018 candidacy

DeSantis announced his candidacy for Governor of Florida in January 2018. He won the Republican primary in August, defeating Agriculture Commissioner Adam Putnam.

In the general election, DeSantis faced Democratic nominee Andrew Gillum, the Mayor of Tallahassee. DeSantis won the election by a margin of 0.4%, or approximately 32,000 votes.

##2022 candidacy

DeSantis announced his re-election campaign in November 2021. He won the Republican primary in August 2022 and went on to defeat Democratic nominee Charlie Crist in the general election.

#Governor of Florida (2019–present)

##Economic

As Governor, DeSantis has prioritized economic growth and job creation. He has supported tax cuts and deregulation, and has worked to attract new businesses to the state.

##Education

DeSantis has been a strong supporter of education reform, including the expansion of school choice programs. He has also advocated for increased funding for public schools.

##Election law and voting rights

DeSantis signed a bill in 2021 that restricted voting rights in Florida, including limits on mail-in voting and voting by felons.

##Abortion limits

DeSantis signed a bill in 2022 that banned abortion in Florida after 15 weeks of pregnancy, with some exceptions.

##Tech platforms

DeSantis has been a vocal critic of tech companies, including Facebook and Twitter, which he has accused of censoring conservative voices.

##COVID-19 response

DeSantis has been a strong opponent of COVID-19 lockdowns and mask mandates. He has advocated for a more relaxed approach to the pandemic, prioritizing individual freedom and economic growth.

##LGBT rights

DeSantis has been a vocal opponent of LGBT rights, including same-sex marriage and transgender rights.

###Dispute with Disney

In 2022, DeSantis became embroiled in a dispute with the Walt Disney Company over the company's opposition to a law that restricted discussion of sexual orientation and gender identity in public schools. DeSantis signed a bill that revoked Disney's special tax status in Florida, leading to a public feud between the Governor and the company.

##Policing and law enforcement

DeSantis has been a strong supporter of law enforcement, including the creation of a new state police force to combat crime.

##Immigration and refugees

DeSantis has been a vocal opponent of immigration and refugee resettlement, including a lawsuit against the federal government over its handling of asylum seekers.

##Hurricane Ian response

DeSantis played a key role in the response to Hurricane Ian, which devastated parts of Florida in 2022. He deployed the National Guard and worked with federal officials to coordinate relief efforts.

##Environment

DeSantis has been a strong supporter of environmental protection, including efforts to clean up the Everglades and protect the state's water resources.

#2024 presidential campaign

DeSantis has been mentioned as a potential candidate for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, although he has not yet announced his candidacy.

#Personal life

DeSantis is married to Casey Black DeSantis, a former television host. The couple has three children together.

#Electoral history

* 2012: U.S. House of Representatives, Florida's 6th congressional district: Ron DeSantis (R) – 57.2%, Heather Beaven (D) – 42.8%
* 2014: U.S. House of Representatives, Florida's 6th congressional district: Ron DeSantis (R) – 62.5%, David Cox (D) – 37.5%
* 2016: U.S. House of Representatives, Florida's 6th congressional district: Ron DeSantis (R) – 58.6%, Bill McCullough (D) – 41.4%
* 2018: Governor of Florida: Ron DeSantis (R) – 49.6%, Andrew Gillum (D) – 49.2%
* 2022: Governor of Florida: Ron DeSantis (R) – 59.4%, Charlie Crist (D) – 40.0%

#Publications

DeSantis has written several articles and book reviews, including:

* "Dreams from Our Founding Fathers" (National Review, 2011)
* "The Case for a Balanced Budget Amendment" (Washington Times, 2012)

2022 Asian Men's U20 Volleyball Championship

The 2022 Asian Men's U20 Volleyball Championship was the 21st edition of the Asian Men's U20 Volleyball Championship, a biennial international volleyball tournament organized by the Asian Volleyball Confederation (AVC) for men's national teams under the age of 20. The tournament was held in Riffa, Bahrain from August 21 to August 29, 2022.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 Asian Men's U20 Volleyball Championship was based on the final standings of the previous edition of the tournament, the 2019 Asian Men's U20 Volleyball Championship.

## Qualified teams

A total of 16 teams qualified for the 2022 Asian Men's U20 Volleyball Championship.

# Format

The tournament was played in two phases: the preliminary round and the final round.

* In the preliminary round, each team played against the other teams in their pool. The top two teams from each pool and the four best third-placed teams advanced to the final round.
