article:
PAOK FC
==========

PAOK FC, commonly known as PAOK, is a Greek professional football club based in Thessaloniki, Macedonia, Greece. Founded in 1926, the club has a rich history and a strong following in Greece and abroad. PAOK FC is one of the most successful and popular football clubs in Greece, with a strong rivalry with Olympiacos and a loyal fan base.

History
--------

### Foundation and early years (1926–1939)

PAOK FC was founded on April 20, 1926, by a group of Greek refugees from Constantinople, who had fled to Thessaloniki after the Greco-Turkish War. The club's name, PAOK, is an acronym for Panthessalonikios Athlitikos Omilos Konstantinoupoliton, which translates to "Pan-Thessalonian Athletic Club of Constantinopolitans". The club's early years were marked by struggles, both on and off the pitch, as the team played in the local Thessaloniki championship.

### Greco-Italian War and World War II (1939–1945)

During World War II, PAOK FC's activities were disrupted due to the war. The club's players and staff were mobilized to fight in the war, and the team's stadium was used as a military hospital. Despite these challenges, PAOK FC continued to play friendly matches and participated in the Thessaloniki championship.

### Macedonia Football Clubs Association (Macedonia Championship) (1946–1959)

After the war, PAOK FC resumed its activities and joined the Macedonia Football Clubs Association (Macedonia Championship). The club won several regional titles during this period and established itself as a major force in Greek football.

### Toumba Stadium and rise of Giorgos Koudas to prominence (1959–1969)

#### First years in Greek National League (Alpha Ethniki)

In 1959, PAOK FC moved to its new home, Toumba Stadium, which was built specifically for the club. The stadium became a fortress for PAOK FC, and the team enjoyed significant success during this period. In 1963, PAOK FC was promoted to the Greek National League (Alpha Ethniki) for the first time in its history.

#### Giorgos Koudas debut and start of the Olympiacos–PAOK rivalry

In 1963, Giorgos Koudas made his debut for PAOK FC and quickly became a fan favorite. Koudas' impressive performances helped establish PAOK FC as a major force in Greek football and sparked a fierce rivalry with Olympiacos.

### 1970s

#### 1975–76 Alpha Ethniki (first league title)

In the 1975-76 season, PAOK FC won its first Greek league title, under the management of Branko Stanković. The team's success was marked by a strong team spirit and the emergence of talented young players.

### 1980s: Professionalism, league title and financial troubles

#### 1984–85 Alpha Ethniki (second league title)

In the 1984-85 season, PAOK FC won its second Greek league title, under the management of Walter Skocik. However, the club's financial troubles began to surface during this period, and the team struggled to maintain its success.

### The Thomas Voulinos era (1989–1996)

Thomas Voulinos became the club's president in 1989 and implemented a series of reforms aimed at stabilizing the club's finances and improving its infrastructure.

### The George Batatoudis era (1996–2003)

George Batatoudis became the club's president in 1996 and oversaw a period of significant investment in the team and its infrastructure.

### The Giannis Goumenos era: troubled times (2003–2006)

Giannis Goumenos became the club's president in 2003, but his tenure was marked by financial struggles and a decline in the team's performance.

### Theodoros Zagorakis – Zisis Vryzas management with massive fans' support (2007–2012)

Theodoros Zagorakis and Zisis Vryzas took over the club's management in 2007 and enjoyed significant success, thanks in part to the massive support of the club's fans.

### The Ivan Savvidis era (2012–present)

#### 2017–18 eventful season

In the 2017-18 season, PAOK FC enjoyed a successful season, finishing second in the Greek league and reaching the quarter-finals of the Greek Cup.

#### 2018–19 unbeaten Champions and first Domestic Double

In the 2018-19 season, PAOK FC won its third Greek league title and its first Domestic Double, under the management of Răzvan Lucescu.

#### 2020–21 Greek Cup winners and 2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League quarter-finalists

In the 2020-21 season, PAOK FC won its eighth Greek Cup title and reached the quarter-finals of the UEFA Europa Conference League.

#### 2023–24 Greek Championship and UEFA Conference League quarter-finalists

In the 2023-24 season, PAOK FC won its fourth Greek league title and reached the quarter-finals of the UEFA Europa Conference League.

Crest and colours
-----------------

### Crest

The club's crest features a golden eagle on a black background, surrounded by a white circle with the club's initials, PAOK.

### Colours

PAOK FC's colours are black and white. The team's home kit is black with white trim, while the away kit is white with black trim.

#### Kit suppliers and shirt sponsors

PAOK FC's kit supplier is Macron, and the club's shirt sponsor is Pame Stoixima.

Facilities
------------

### Toumba Stadium

Toumba Stadium is PAOK FC's home stadium, with a capacity of 28,703. The stadium was built in 1959 and has undergone several renovations over the years.

### New Toumba Stadium project

PAOK FC is currently building a new stadium, which is expected to be completed in 2025. The new stadium will have a capacity of 40,000 and will feature state-of-the-art facilities.

### Training ground

PAOK FC's training ground is located in the suburb of Thermi, Thessaloniki. The training ground features several pitches and a gym.

### New Training Center Thermi

PAOK FC is currently building a new training center in Thermi, which is expected to be completed in 2024. The new training center will feature state-of-the-art facilities and will be used by the club's first team and youth teams.

Supporters
------------

### Vale of Tempe tragedy (1999)

In 1999, two PAOK FC fans were killed in a car accident on their way to a match against Olympiacos. The incident led to a outpouring of grief and solidarity from the club's fans and the wider football community.

### Supporters friendships

PAOK FC has strong friendships with several other football clubs, including Besiktas JK and Partizan Belgrade.

### Rivalries

PAOK FC has fierce rivalries with Olympiacos and AEK Athens. The club's matches against these teams are always highly anticipated and closely contested.

article:
September 2022 United Kingdom mini-budget

The September 2022 United Kingdom mini-budget was a fiscal event delivered by Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng on 23 September 2022. The budget, officially known as the "Growth Plan 2022", outlined significant tax cuts and increased borrowing to fund energy subsidies and other measures. The announcement was met with widespread criticism and market volatility, leading to a series of events that ultimately resulted in the resignation of Prime Minister Liz Truss.

# Background

The mini-budget was announced in the context of a cost of living crisis in the United Kingdom, with high inflation and rising energy prices affecting households and businesses. The government had already implemented some measures to address the crisis, including a price cap on energy bills and a windfall tax on energy companies. However, the mini-budget represented a more significant shift in economic policy, with a focus on tax cuts and deregulation to stimulate growth.

# The budget

## Key points

The key points of the mini-budget included:

* A reduction in the basic rate of income tax from 20% to 19%
* The abolition of the 45% top rate of income tax
* A reduction in the rate of corporation tax from 25% to 19%
* The reversal of the national insurance increase introduced in April 2022
* The cancellation of the planned increase in the dividend tax rate
* The introduction of a new " Investment Zones" scheme to encourage investment in specific areas
* The provision of £60 billion in energy subsidies to households and businesses

# Reaction

## Currency, interest rate, and debt

The announcement of the mini-budget led to a sharp decline in the value of the pound sterling against other major currencies, including the US dollar and the euro. This was partly due to the increased borrowing required to fund the tax cuts and energy subsidies, which raised concerns about the sustainability of the UK's public finances. The yield on UK government bonds also increased, indicating that investors were demanding higher returns to compensate for the perceived increase in risk.

## Bond markets

The bond markets were severely affected by the mini-budget, with the yield on 10-year UK government bonds rising to 4.5%, the highest level since 2008. This led to concerns about the impact on mortgage rates and the broader economy. The Bank of England was forced to intervene in the bond market to prevent a complete collapse in confidence.

## International response

The international community was largely critical of the mini-budget, with many commentators expressing concerns about the impact on global markets and the UK's economic stability. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) issued a statement expressing concern about the budget's potential impact on inflation and the UK's public finances.

## Business and economic

The business community was also critical of the mini-budget, with many expressing concerns about the impact on inflation and the broader economy. The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) issued a statement expressing concern about the budget's potential impact on business investment and the UK's competitiveness.

## Media

The media reaction to the mini-budget was overwhelmingly negative, with many commentators expressing concerns about the impact on the UK's economic stability and the government's judgment. The BBC, ITV, and Sky News all featured critical analysis of the budget, with many commentators questioning the government's decision to implement such significant tax cuts.

## Political

The opposition Labour Party was highly critical of the mini-budget, with Leader Keir Starmer describing it as "a budget for the wealthy, paid for by the rest of us". The Liberal Democrats also expressed concerns about the budget's potential impact on the UK's public finances and the environment.

## Opinion polling

The mini-budget was widely unpopular with the public, with many opinion polls showing that a majority of voters opposed the tax cuts and energy subsidies. A YouGov poll found that 71% of voters opposed the abolition of the 45% top rate of income tax, while a Survation poll found that 62% of voters opposed the reduction in the basic rate of income tax.

# Government response

## Initial responses

The government initially defended the mini-budget, with Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng arguing that the tax cuts and energy subsidies were necessary to stimulate growth and address the cost of living crisis. Prime Minister Liz Truss also defended the budget, arguing that it was necessary to take bold action to address the UK's economic challenges.

## Dismissal of Chancellor

However, as the criticism of the mini-budget mounted, the government was forced to take action. On 14 October 2022, Prime Minister Liz Truss announced that Kwasi Kwarteng had been dismissed as Chancellor, to be replaced by Jeremy Hunt. Hunt immediately announced that he would be reversing many of the tax cuts and energy subsidies announced in the mini-budget.

## Reversal of tax cuts

On 17 October 2022, Jeremy Hunt announced that the government would be reversing many of the tax cuts announced in the mini-budget, including the abolition of the 45% top rate of income tax and the reduction in the basic rate of income tax. Hunt also announced that the government would be introducing a new windfall tax on energy companies to help fund the energy subsidies.

# Resignation of Truss as Prime Minister

On 25 October 2022, Liz Truss announced that she would be resigning as Prime Minister, to be replaced by Rishi Sunak. Truss's resignation came after a tumultuous period in office, marked by widespread criticism of her economic policies and a series of U-turns.

# Subsequent events

## Following Truss's resignation

Following Truss's resignation, the new Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced that he would be taking a more cautious approach to economic policy, with a focus on stabilizing the public finances and addressing the cost of living crisis. Sunak also announced that he would be reversing many of the tax cuts and energy subsidies announced in the mini-budget.

## Later events

In the months following the mini-budget, the UK economy continued to face significant challenges, including high inflation and rising interest rates. The government was forced to take further action to address the cost of living crisis, including increasing the minimum wage and introducing new measures to support households and businesses.

# See also

Lock Upp Season 1

Lock Upp is an Indian reality television series that premiered on February 27, 2022, on ALTBalaji and MX Player. The show is hosted by Kangana Ranaut and is produced by Endemol Shine India. The series features a unique concept where contestants, known as "inmates," are locked up in a jail-like setting and compete with each other to win the title of "Ultimate Lock Upp Winner."

# Overview

Lock Upp Season 1 is the first season of the reality television series Lock Upp. The show was announced in January 2022, and the contestants were revealed on February 24, 2022. The season premiered on February 27, 2022, and concluded on May 7, 2022.

## Concept

The concept of Lock Upp is based on a unique format where contestants are locked up in a jail-like setting and compete with each other to win the title of "Ultimate Lock Upp Winner." The contestants are divided into two teams, and each team has to work together to complete tasks and challenges. The team that wins the most challenges gets to stay in the luxurious part of the jail, while the losing team has to stay in the ordinary part. The contestants also have to nominate each other for elimination, and the contestant with the most nominations gets eliminated.

article:
Ek Villain Returns
================

Ek Villain Returns is a 2022 Indian Hindi-language action thriller film directed by Mohit Suri and produced by Balaji Motion Pictures. The film is a spiritual sequel to the 2014 film Ek Villain and features an ensemble cast, including John Abraham, Arjun Kapoor, Disha Patani, and Tara Sutaria.

Plot
-----

The film follows the story of two young men, Bhairav Purohit (John Abraham) and Gautam Mehra (Arjun Kapoor), who are on a mission to avenge the death of their loved ones. Bhairav, a former cop, is driven by a desire to punish the culprit who killed his wife, while Gautam, a wealthy businessman, seeks to avenge the murder of his girlfriend.

As the two men embark on their respective journeys, they cross paths with two women, Rasika Mapuskar (Disha Patani) and Aarvi Malhotra (Tara Sutaria), who are connected to their quests for revenge. Rasika, a free-spirited woman, becomes embroiled in Bhairav's mission, while Aarvi, a college student, finds herself drawn into Gautam's world.

As the story unfolds, the four characters become entangled in a complex web of love, revenge, and betrayal. Along the way, they must confront their own demons and make difficult choices that will ultimately determine their fate.

Cast
-----

* John Abraham as Bhairav Purohit
* Arjun Kapoor as Gautam Mehra
* Disha Patani as Rasika Mapuskar
* Tara Sutaria as Aarvi Malhotra
* J. D. Chakravarthy as Rakesh Mahadkar
* Shaad Randhawa as Vishal

Production
-----------

### Casting

The casting process for Ek Villain Returns began in 2020, with John Abraham and Arjun Kapoor being the first actors to be cast in the film. Disha Patani and Tara Sutaria were later added to the cast, with Patani playing the role of Rasika Mapuskar and Sutaria playing the role of Aarvi Malhotra.

### Filming

Principal photography for the film began in July 2021 and took place in various locations, including Mumbai, Goa, and Pune. The film's director, Mohit Suri, worked closely with the cast and crew to ensure that the film's action sequences and dramatic scenes were executed flawlessly.

Soundtrack
----------

The soundtrack for Ek Villain Returns was composed by Tanishk Bagchi, with lyrics written by Kumaar, Manoj Muntashir, and Prince Dubey. The album features five tracks, including the hit single "Galliyan Returns," which was sung by Ankit Tiwari and Manoj Muntashir.

Reception
----------

### Box Office

Ek Villain Returns was released in theaters on July 29, 2022, and opened to a decent response at the box office. The film earned approximately ₹10 crore on its opening day and went on to gross over ₹50 crore in its first week. Despite facing competition from other releases, the film managed to hold its own and emerged as a moderate success.

### Critical Response

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the performances of the lead actors and others criticizing the film's plot and direction. The Times of India gave the film 3 out of 5 stars, stating that it was a "slick and stylish thriller" with "impressive performances" from the cast. However, the Indian Express gave the film 2 out of 5 stars, calling it a " mess of a movie" with a " convoluted plot."

Release
-------

### Theatrical

Ek Villain Returns was released in theaters on July 29, 2022, in India and other countries. The film was released in multiple languages, including Hindi, Tamil, and Telugu.

### Home Media

The film's digital rights were acquired by Netflix, and it was made available for streaming on the platform on September 9, 2022. The film's DVD and Blu-ray copies were also released in October 2022.

References
----------

2022–23 UEFA Europa Conference League

The 2022–23 UEFA Europa Conference League is the second season of the UEFA Europa Conference League, Europe's tertiary club football tournament organized by UEFA. The season is scheduled to run from 7 July 2022 to 7 June 2023. The final match will be played at the Fortuna Arena in Prague, Czech Republic.

# Association team allocation

## Association ranking

For the 2022–23 UEFA Europa Conference League, the associations are allocated places according to their 2021 UEFA country coefficients, which take into account their performance in European competitions from the 2016–17 to the 2020–21 seasons.

## Distribution

A total of 184 teams from 54 of the 55 UEFA member associations participate in the 2022–23 UEFA Europa Conference League. The association ranking determines the number of teams allocated to each association. The top five associations have two teams qualifying for the Europa Conference League, while the next five associations have one team qualifying.

## Teams

The teams are divided into four categories:

* Champions of the top 50 national associations, not qualifying for the Champions League.
* Runners-up of the top 50 national associations, not qualifying for the Champions League or Europa League.
* Third-placed teams of the top 50 national associations, not qualifying for the Champions League or Europa League.
* Domestic cup winners of the top 50 national associations, not qualifying for the Champions League or Europa League.

2022 Pakistani Airstrikes in Afghanistan

The 2022 Pakistani airstrikes in Afghanistan refer to a series of airstrikes conducted by the Pakistani military on April 16, 2022, against targets in eastern Afghanistan. The airstrikes were reportedly aimed at terrorist groups operating in the region, including the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), a militant organization that has been responsible for numerous attacks on Pakistani soil.

#Background

The airstrikes were part of a broader operation launched by Pakistan to target terrorist groups operating along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. In recent years, the TTP and other militant groups have taken advantage of the porous border to launch attacks on Pakistani cities and military installations. In response, the Pakistani military has stepped up its efforts to eliminate these groups, including through airstrikes and ground operations.

Prior to the airstrikes, Pakistani officials had warned the Afghan government of the presence of TTP militants in eastern Afghanistan. Pakistan had also requested that the Afghan government take action against the TTP, but these requests had been met with little success. The airstrikes were seen as a last resort by the Pakistani military to target the TTP and other militant groups.
